A lot of people think that those who support Robert Griffin III, particularly, the African-American fans, do so simply because of his race. That may or may not be true. It's definitely not in my case because when Tony Banks played here, I hated him. Then there's the flip-side of the argument. Those that hate him BECAUSE he's Black. Find the comment by Liam Livingston that starts with "I am starting to think Griffin is retarded...". Read the subsequent comments and tell me what you think his dislike stems from. Treat yourself to his wonderful dialog of him calling me "boy", telling me to take off my "thug cap" and most amusing, him telling me to educate myself. Reading both our comments should clear the argument of who needs an education. I took screenshots, but unfortunately, I can't post them. Liam Livingston, I'm calling you what you are: an inbred, uneducated bigot. Sorry, I had to get that off my chest

Coverage of pro-sport now focuses more on locker room drama while athletes are changing and showering etc. than on the action on the playing surface. The locker room is now a vulgar side show. There are hundreds of men and women, camera crews, sound people and now, bloggers. It's an offensive freaking naked beefcake show courtesy by management and media. It's exploitation and objectification of naked young male athletes. Management makes it an obligatory condition in their contracts. Here‚Äôs an example of what I'm talking about.

http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=whitlock/050811
There have been many athletes who have spoken out, only to be fined, disciplined, shamed, ridiculed, vilified and told to "man up‚Äù by management and media. It‚Äôs the same stoic, shut up and man up garbage that predisposes the young victims of the Jerry Sandusky‚Äôs and Graham James‚Äôs of this world. That‚Äôs the message organized male pro-sport is sending to young men and boys. It tells them that men have no rights to boundaries. Then we wonder why some of them grow up not to respect the boundaries of others? So now the athletes have resigned themselves to it. We would never do this to women. If you don't believe me look at the different policies between the NBA and the WNBA. Male reporters are never allowed in when the women are naked. The action takes place on the playing surface, not the locker room. Get the bloody media voyeurs out of the locker room.

Coverage of pro-sport now focuses more on locker room drama while athletes are changing and showering etc. than on the action on the playing surface. The locker room is now a vulgar side show. There are hundreds of men and women, camera crews, sound people and now, bloggers. It's an offensive freaking naked beefcake show courtesy by management and media. It's exploitation and objectification of naked young male athletes. Management makes it an obligatory condition in their contracts. Here‚Äôs an example of what I'm talking about.

http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=whitlock/050811
There have been many athletes who have spoken out, only to be fined, disciplined, shamed, ridiculed, vilified and told to "man up‚Äù by management and media. It‚Äôs the same stoic, shut up and man up garbage that predisposes the young victims of the Jerry Sandusky‚Äôs and Graham James‚Äôs of this world. That‚Äôs the message organized male pro-sport is sending to young men and boys. It tells them that men have no rights to boundaries. Then we wonder why some of them grow up not to respect the boundaries of others? So now the athletes have resigned themselves to it. We would never do this to women. If you don't believe me look at the different policies between the NBA and the WNBA. Male reporters are never allowed in when the women are naked. The action takes place on the playing surface, not the locker room. Get the bloody media voyeurs out of the locker room.

Sportswriter Richard Justice recounts my favorite Joe Gibbs story while being interviewed for a Washington Post piece recalling the '91 Skins:  Fans were screaming at Rypien before one game, and when Gibbs walked by him, Rypien said, ``The natives are restless, coach.'' Gibbs walks over to a group of fans and asks, ``Who's yelling at our quarterback?'' They pointed to one guy. Gibbs looked at the guy and said, ``We need you today.'' The guy completely changed demeanor and said, ``I'm with you, coach.'' Gibbs had more people skills than any 10 other people I've ever known in my life. He'd hold these Monday team meetings and give out awards, and it was magical how it brought the team together.

data.message: Playoffs ? How about the Superbowl
Redskins has zero chances of going to Super Bowl with RGIII.

ESPN asked 35 anonymous NFL insiders to place each of the league‚Äôs 32 projected starting quarterbacks into one of five tiers, with Tier 1 representing the best and Tier 5 representing the worst. The results of the second annual ‚ÄúQuarterback Tiers‚Äù project (Insider subscription required) were not kind to projected Redskins starter Robert Griffin III. Griffin was placed in the fourth tier with an average ranking of 3.91. He ranked 28th among QBs after tying for 19th and being placed in the third tier last season. No QBs qualified for the fifth tier, but at least one of the insiders is convinced that‚Äôs where Griffin belongs. ‚ÄúFive, and there‚Äôs no coming back,‚Äù one offensive coach said of Griffin. ‚ÄúHe is done. The reason why is, the injury slowed his legs, and his ego will not allow him to hit rock bottom and actually grind his way back up the right way.‚Äù Another respondent suggested Griffin is delusional and lacks humility. ‚ÄúGriffin sees himself like Peyton [Manning], in that light,‚Äù a personnel director said. ‚ÄúWhen he looks in the mirror, he is seeing things that everybody else is not seeing. That is why I was surprised when they gave him the fifth-year [option] and said it was an easy decision.‚Äù START COUSINS!

With an improved o-line, an experienced qb coach and plenty of time to be 100% healthy there should be no excuses for playing poorly. If he's playing good and they still lose, then they need to address the problem next off season or sooner if possible. The other qbs have been sharpening their skills too. If he isn't getting the job done by week 3 they need to make a change. With the improvements made, coaches and players, the qb doesn't have to be great for this team to make the playoffs. An average qb should be able to do well with this offense. Saying that the new o-line stays healthy. Injuries would be a major set back.

data.name: Bleacher Report Gives Redskins Strong Offseason Grade

data.message: This is not said every year!! The Redskins are a joke every offseason. We usually make one or two huge splash moves. This was the first good offseason in years and you guys are still complaining.

A lot of folks are still salty about the hiring of Barry as defensive coordinator with his history of being in Detroit.  Let's keep in mind the talent he was supplied for his unit came at the hands of one Matt Millen.  The book has yet to be written on how he does in his first year here, but he will have way more talent than he probably did any year he was up Detroit.  Offensively the additions that were most important other than Scherff were assistants.  Offensive line coach and quarterback coach of Callahan's and Cavanaugh's experience has been needed since at least 2010.  We've had six quarterbacks who started in at least one game that were subpar in that time.  The one who was the most successful is still our starter; this season he'll have the most help from the coaching staff than he's had since he came into the league.  He has a position coach, a real one of which we probably haven't had since the 80s, who has 35+ years experience in the league as player and coach as a QB and a line coach who should teach those dudes how to protect, as well as open holes for 46; who should be the man as long as he's durable and doing what he's been doing since he came into the league.  Dude doesn't get hurt, except for the game in Oakland.  Last year a new head coach was hired; but this was the offseason where we've made the most needed changes, front office, coaches, and players, probably since the 90s.  Nothing that happened on the field last year should have any bearing on this year.  Won't even matter.  This is a new era; and we'll see at kickoff how much improvement we've made.......
Ugh.   I don't care about the offseason grades.  The actual season's record is the ONLY grade.

I've been a Redskins fan since the one season Vince Lombardi was Head Coach. Lots of ups and downs. It has been 23 years since we've won a Super Bowl. But the fact that this has been a quiet off season is a very good sign. I predict a 9-7 season, which will be a huge improvement.

We usually are the off-season champs. To be fair, unlike all the previous years, this time we have a GM who knows what he's doing. But it takes time to build a team. I don't think we'll be that great this year. Or next year. And we could be set back a few more years if RG3 doesn't develop as an NFL QB and/or Gruden doesn't develop as an NFL head coach
What did they do this offseason

Anything we did in the offseason in years past, or on the field in past years is immaterial.  The people who brought the talent in in years past did not have the focus of this GM.  He is building a team identity; which we haven't had since Joe II.    Not just players, but assistants too.  Notice the assistants were hired after Scot.  Too many changes have been made this offseason to relate last year to what may happen this season.  A new philosophy brought in by two offensive assistants should correct the ineffective play behind center and the ineptitude of our pass blocking.  New assistants and talent on defense should make that unit better.  We might not make the playoffs, or even be .500; but the team has finally added pieces needed for years.  We don't have to worry about coaches making final personnel decisions, or incompetent front office people who have no clue about finding players (or coaches for that matter.  Gruden isn't even Scot's guy; he's gone after a bad season.  Not because he's terrible, but because he's not a coach Scot would've hired).  Other than that, a lot of players we had last year will be different players this year; just by coaching; much of which we didn't have last year....

Honestly, as a lifelong Redskins, I was like 2 when they won their last Super Bowl, so obviously I haven't seen much success.  I was excited when we drafted RG3, I really was.  He is mentally on permanent IR, since he was injured in the Baltimore Game.  If you looked at him in the Philly game two weeks later, he wasn't the same, and he was extremely inaccurate against Dallas in Week 17.  The playoff game did start out well, 14-0, then he twerked his knee again and wasn't the same.  Since 2012, the Redskins have gone 7-25.  Kirk Cousins was given a shot at starting at the end of 2013 and went 0-3.  It wasn't a fair shot though, half the team had already checked out of the season mentally and Shanahan was already out the door.  So when Robert went down in Week 2 of 2014 and Kirk stepped in, he shredded the Jacksonville defense.  Granted, it was the Jacksonville defense.  The next week, he did the same thing against a fairly good Philly defense.  Only 1 interception that game.  Did they win it, no they didn't, but Kirk proved he can throw.  4 days later, he threw 4 interceptions against the Giants.  And preceded to go down since then.  Except for the Seattle game.  The same seattle seahawks who won the super bowl the year prior and had the famous Legion of Boom.  He didn't turn the ball over in that game.  Only reason they couldn't get a win that game, was because they kept getting pinned behind their own 10 yard line and the playcalling was terrible as well as a bad O-Line.  Robert is the starter going into training camp.  I think that Gruden should alternate the starters though.  Let Kirk or Colt start game 1 or 2, and still let Robert play in those games, let Robert start in Game 3 the dress rehearsal.  Then make a decision before game 4 of the preseason to who really should be the starter.
